instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2879: What is 820-2879? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SCL: What is SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SCL? SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SCL is another way to say SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL, look at the definition provided for SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL as it applies to .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Dropping from 12.6 to ~5V then back to 12.6
threads.message: So I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> were <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> will sit at 12.6V for a few seconds then slowly drop to 5V sit there for a few seconds then back to 12.6 and repeats. I think i have narrowed it down to <SIGNAL>CHGR_AGATE</SIGNAL> it will be at 16V then drop down to 6V for a bit then back to 16 causing <TRANSISTOR>Q7085</TRANSISTOR> to not output the correct voltage. This happened with or without F7040 on the board. Does anyone have any idea why this is happening and how to fix it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Dropping from 12.6 to ~5V then back to 12.6
threads.message: voltage is stable at pin 2 from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>?? check sense resistors from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> (<RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR>), corrosion on <RESISTOR>R7085</RESISTOR>-<RESISTOR>R7086</RESISTOR> or around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>???  if everything is right remove F7040 and check if 12.6V stabilizes...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Dropping from 12.6 to ~5V then back to 12.6
threads.message: voltage seams stable at pin 2 of the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> ~16.3V. All the current sense resistors are fine. And yes it drops even with F7040 removed

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Dropping from 12.6 to ~5V then back to 12.6
threads.message: Is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> pulsing too? What is the history, liquid?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Dropping from 12.6 to ~5V then back to 12.6
threads.message: I believe <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> was pulsing as well. But i went to go mess with this board today and it magically lost its green light over night and now has a short to ground on <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>. This board is going to meet the bottom of the pile for a little bit.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Dropping from 12.6 to ~5V then back to 12.6
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is going to enable <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, which comes from the SMC.

<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SCL</SIGNAL>/<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_BSA_SDA</SIGNAL> talk to the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> to set the voltage of <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, which come from the SMC.

<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>, which you say is shorted to ground, connects through the SMC.

See a pattern? :)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2879</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> Dropping from 12.6 to ~5V then back to 12.6
threads.message: I do... Sadly... And this is why this board is sitting in the pile. :p
